questiontext.text:
[London] is the capital city of the UK, more people live there than any other city. Birmingham is the largest city outside London 

with a population of around 3.8 million people. It is approximately 110 miles from London and is a major international commerce centre. Birmingham is a major transport hub on the motorway, rail and [canal] networks.

The city is served by the M5, M6, M40, and M42 motorways, and probably the best known motorway junction in the UK: [Spaghetti] [Junction]. Birmingham Airport is located 6 miles (9.7 km) [east] of the city centre in the neighbouring borough of Solihull.

The National Express Group headquarters are located in [Digbeth], in offices above Birmingham Coach Station, which forms the national hub of the company's coach network. Birmingham is home to five universities: Aston University, University of Birmingham, Birmingham City University, University College Birmingham and Newman University.

question.introduction:
• Identify the water based transport mentioned in the text.
  • Where is the main coach station in Birmingham (one word)
  • In what direction from the city centre is the airport (one word)
  • What is the famous motorway interchange mentioned in the text (two words)
  • Which city in the UK has the biggest population?

questiontext.text:
The University of Cambridge is in Cambridge, [England]. It is the second-oldest university in all English-speaking countries (after [Oxford]). It is one of the world's leading places of learning.

The University started as a group of scholars in 1209, when scholars left Oxford after a fight with local people. The universities of Oxford and Cambridge are often called [Oxbridge]. This is not a different university. It is a way of saying Oxford and Cambridge together. Cambridge University and Oxford University are both very important to the history of England.

question.introduction:
• What country is Cambridge University in?
  • In English speaking countries, which is the oldest university?
  • What word is used to say Oxford and Cambridge together

questiontext.text: Charles Dickens was born in [Portsmouth] and lived there until he was twelve yers old. Then his family moved to Camden, London. He became a famous [writer] and with many successful novels such as Oliver Twist.He got a job as an office boy for lawyer. After finding that job dull, he taught himself [shorthand] and became a journalist . He died of a [stroke] on June 9, 1870.

question.introduction:
Select one word to answer each question

  • In what town did he spend his childhood?
  • What did he do for a living that made him famous? 
  • What skill did he learn in order to change jobs?
  • What killed him?

questiontext.text:
A competition or contest is an event where people get together to see who is the best at something. Someone who takes part in a competition ("enters for a competition") is called a competitor. The competitors compete against one another. The person who wins may get a [prize].

Competitions can be for all sorts of things: sport, writing, music, dancing, science, chess etc.There will probably be a [referee]. They will make sure that the game is played fairly and that the competitors obey the rules.

question.introduction:
• What is given to the person who is best in a competition?
  • What is the name of the person who ensures a competition is fair.

questiontext.text:
Cricket is a  sport which is played between two teams of [eleven] players each who score runs (points) by running between two sets of three small, wooden posts called wickets. Each of the wickets is at one end of a rectangle of flattened grass called the [pitch]. 

The game started in England in the 16th century. The earliest definite reference to the sport is in a court case of [1598]. The court in Guildford heard a coroner, John Derrick, that when he was a scholar at the "Free School at Guildford", fifty years earlier, "he and diverse of his fellows did run and play [on the common land] at cricket and other players". Later, the game spread to countries of the British Empire in the 19th and 20th centuries.

question.introduction:
• How many people are in a cricket team?
  • What is the name for the area where cricket is played?
  • In what year was the first reference to cricket?

questiontext.text:
One of the most popular types of restaurant in the UK is the "Curry house". These are typically run by people from the Indian sub-continent. The food is more spicy than traditional British food, and include things such as [chilli], [cumin] and [turmeric].

One of the most popular dishes is [Chicken] Tikka Masala, which is believed to have been invented in the UK. Some people say that the most typical British night out involves a curry and a [lager]. Some cities have become famous for this type of food, particularly where there are large populations from Asia. Examples are [Bradford] and [Leciester].

question.introduction:
Select four ingredients mentioned in the text.
What type of drink is mentioned in the text?
Which places are mentioned that are famous for curry in the UK?

questiontext.text:
A medical doctor (also called a [physician]) is a person who practices medicine to treat illness and injuries. Medical doctors go to medical school to be trained. They usually hold a college degree in medicine. Medical doctors used to make house calls to treat patients at home. Now they usually see patients in their offices or in hospitals. Medical doctors may also work for schools, companies, sports teams, or the military. Medical doctors are often assisted by [nurses].

Medical doctors treat patients by diagnosing them or figuring out what is wrong. They begin by asking questions about the patient's symptoms. Symptoms might include fever or pain. They may ask other questions about things like past illnesses or family members who have been sick. They will then examine the patient. That can include looking at different parts of the body and listening to the heart and lungs with a [stethoscope].

Some medical doctors do only certain kinds of medicine. These doctors are called [specialists]. They may treat injuries to only specific parts of the body. They may treat only patients who have certain diseases. Other medical doctors are "general practitioners" or "family practitioners". This means that they do a little bit of everything.

question.introduction:
• What is the alternative name for a medical doctor?
  • What person helps out doctors?
  • What type of doctor focusses on particular types of medicine?
  • What device is used to examine the parts of the body used for breathing?

questiontext.text: In [England] pupils study for the [GCSE] exams normally between the ages of 14 and 16. Every student must study English and Maths. To pass the exams a student must get a grade C. After that they can study either A levels or a Vocational subject, sometimes called a BTEC qualification. This is called [Further] [Education].  These qualifications are considered more practical with less emphasis on writing about the subject. For example people study BTEC's in childcare and motor vehicle repair. After that a student can go on to University. There is a central organisation for applying to university called UCAS.  In [Scotland] the education system is slightly different but the stages are similar.

question.introduction:
• What is the name of the exams studied before A levels
  • What is the name of education after the age of 16? (two words)
  • What are the two countries named in the text?

questiontext.text:
[Brian] had a sister called [Jane]. Every [summer] he would take his wife Louise and son Peter to visit her.
She had a wonderful house with a big garden for him to play in. George and Louise were delighted when Peter married [Anne] when he was 23.

Anne worked as a nurse and Peter worked as a teacher. They bought a house and were very happy. Two years later they had a baby, a boy they called Luke. A year later they had a girl who they named Louise.

question.introduction:
• What is the name of  is Lukes Grandfather?
  • What is Peters wife's name?
  • What is the name of Luke's sister?
  • When did they visit Jane?
  • What is the name of Peters aunt?

questiontext.text:
Fish and Chips is a popular take-away meal in the UK. Haddock is sometimes used but, [cod] is by far the most popular. Other fish with white meat can be used as well, for example whiting or plaice. The phrase 'fish & chips' implies that it will be [fried] in [batter].

Of course, in a fish restaurant, grilling or boiling would be alternatives. Typically Fish and Chips is eaten with salt and vinegar. Fish and Chip shops also offer other savoury items such as sausages, pies and fish cakes. Some Fish and chip shops offer eat-in options where you can sit at a table to eat your meal.

question.introduction:
• Which is the most commonly used fish?
  • What is the fish covered in before cooking?
  • How is the fish cooked?

questiontext.text: The "Full English Breakfast", is a dish consisting of [fried] food. Typically it includes egg, bacon, mushrooms and sometimes tomatoes and toast. The exact ingrediants vary and there are Scottish, Irish and Welsh variations. Because it is a high calorie meal people typically eat something lighter most days, leaving the Full English for the [weekend]. A typical weekday breakfast is [cereal] or [toast].

question.introduction:
• How is the "Full English Breakfast" cooked?
  • When is it eaten?
  • What to people tend to eat from Monday to Friday?

questiontext.text: J. K. Rowling is the British author of the Harry Potter books. She grew up in [Gloucestershire] and got her degree at the University of Exeter. She worked at Amnesty International in [London] and then she moved to Portugal to teach English. She is a [Christian].

question.introduction:
Select one word for each answer

  • What county did she live in as a child
  • Where was her first job mentioned in the text
  • What is her religion?

questiontext.text:
England became one country in 937. The first King of England was [Athelstan], but he lost a lot of land to Danish invaders, who formed their own country in the East and North. Many villages and towns in this area particularly in Yorkshire, still have Danish names, and use some Danish-based words. At one time Wessex (in the West of England) was the only English kingdom left. After many battles, King [Alfred] the Great of Wessex became king of the whole of England, and the old kingdoms (Mercia, Northumberland, etc.) just became provinces, called "Earldoms" governed by an "Earl". Soon after Alfred died, the king of Denmark Canute ruled England.


England soon had an English king again. When King Edward the Confessor died, Harold (the Earl of Wessex) became king. [William] the Conqueror, Duke of Normandy (today part of northern France), said that Harold Godwinson had promised to make him  king, so he invaded England and fought King Harold at the Battle of [Hastings] in 1066.

He won, and then became king of England. The kings of England spoke [French] for the next 300 years. England took over the country of Wales in the 13th century. There were many wars, often against France and Scotland.

For many centuries the religion of England was Roman Catholicism. The bishops (church leaders) of England and all their churches obeyed the pope and the church in Rome, Italy. During the Protestant Reformation many of the bishops did not agree with this. In the 1530s, the Pope told King Henry VIII that he could not divorce his wife. King Henry VIII created the Church of England (a "Protestant" church) so that he could divorce his wife, and made it the official church in England.

question.introduction:
• Who was the first king of England?
  • Who was the first king of all of England?
  • What language did the kings of England speak after 1066
  • Which king established the Church of England?
  • Where was the battle that resulted in William becoming king?
  • Who was the first Norman king?

questiontext.text:
Liverpool is a city in the north west of [England]. It was most famous as a port during the late 19th and early 20th century. It is the birthplace of the famous rock group The [Beatles]. It is also famous because of its [football] teams, Liverpool F.C. and Everton F.C.

People from Liverpool are called Liverpudlians or Scousers. The city's primary mainline station is [Lime] [Street], which acts as a terminus for several lines into the city. Liverpool was home to both the Cunard and White Star Line, and was the port of registry of the ocean liner RMS [Titanic] famous for sinking on its first voyage.

question.introduction:
• What musicians from Liverpool are named in the text?
  • What country is Liverpool in?
  • What ship is mentioned in the text?
  • Where is the main place to catch trains in Liverpool (two words)
  • Which sport is mentioned in the text?

questiontext.text:
• How many people live in London?
  • What is the word for visitors who come for pleasure?
  • Select the word for people move to London from another country

London is the capital and largest city of England and the United Kingdom. The river Thames travels through the city and is 346km long. London is the biggest city in western Europe, and the world's largest financial centre.

London is one of the world's most important cities for business, finance, and politics. It is also important for culture: media, entertainment, fashion, and art.

The population of London is around [8,500,000]. Most people in London are British. However, London also has many [immigrants]. These people come from many different countries. They speak many different languages and have different religions and cultures. There are also many people from different countries who stay in London on business. Many people visit London as [tourists]. They may see the famous "Sights of London". These sights include palaces, churches and museums.

Manchester is a major in England, with a population of 520,000. To the south of Manchester is the the Cheshire Plain, to the north the Pennine Hills.

The recorded history of Manchester began with the civilian settlement associated with the Roman fort of Mamucium or Mancunium, which was established in about 79 AD. Manchester's unplanned expansion was brought on by a boom in the manufacture of [textiles] during the Industrial Revolution, and resulted in it becoming the world's first industrialised city.

The [Manchester] [Ship] [Canal] opened in 1894, creating the Port of Manchester and linking the city to sea, 36 miles (58 km) to the west. Its fortunes declined after the Second World War, owing to deindustrialisation. The city centre was devastated in a bombing in [1996], but it led to extensive investment and regeneration that has since helped it turn into a thriving 'reborn' modern city.

There are three universities in the City of Manchester. The University of Manchester, Manchester Metropolitan University and Royal Northern College of Music. The University of Manchester is the largest full-time non-collegiate university in the United Kingdom and was created in 2004 by the merger of Victoria University of Manchester founded in 1904 and UMIST, founded in 1956, though the university's logo appears to claim it was established in 1824. It includes the Manchester Business School, which offered the first [MBA] in the UK in 1965.

question.introduction:
• What was the main thing made in Manchesters Factories?
  • What is the waterway mentioned in the text (three words)
  • In what year was the explosion that caused damage to central Manchester
  • What post graduate course is mentioned in the text

questiontext.text: The Moodle Virtual Learning Environment was first developed by Martin Dougiamas from [Perth] in Western Australia. It was first released to the public in [2001] and by 2017 had more than 96 million users around the world. It is now usable on mobile phones, wither with a mobile browser, or via an app which requires a [download] from Apple or Google. One of the most commonly used modules is [Assignment] which allows teachers to set work and the students then upload their work when complete.

question.introduction:
• What town does Martin Dougiams come from?
  • In what year did Moodle first become available?
  • What must you do to to get the app?
  • Which is one of the most frequently used features of Moodle?

questiontext.text: My father John, was the oldest of two children , his brother [Tom] was born two years after him. For his degree he studied [Agriculture] but only worked in that area for a year. He retrained as a computer programmer and got a job with [IBM]. He worked for them for ten years and then set up his own company in partnership with his friend Fredrick Smith. He employed an assistant called [Jane], and two years after they met they married.

question.introduction:
• Who was the name of the youngest member of the family?
  • What was his subject at University?
  • Who employed him after he left agriculture?
  • What was the name of the person who worked for him?

questiontext.text: The English language has developed over hundreds of years. It has its origins in Anglo Saxon languages with a strong influence from French due to the Norman conquest in the year [1066]. It has also borrowed many words from other parts of the world. For example the words pajama, [bungalow] and shampoo.  There are subtle differences between UK and American English, for example what is called the [pavement] in the UK is called the [sidewalk] in the US.

question.introduction:
• Select the word that means a single storey house.
  • When did the army from France invade England?
  • Select both words that mean the area of a road reserved for pedestrians.

questiontext.text:
Penicillin is an antibiotic that was one of the first medications to be effective against many bacterial infections. Many strains of baceria are now resistant. [Chemists] keep changing part of its structure in the effort to keep it working against the bacteria.

Penicillin was discovered by Scottish scientist Sir Alexander Fleming in [1928], but it was not mass-produced until the 1940s. The antibiotic is naturally produced by [fungi] of the genus Penicillium. There is now a whole group of antibiotics derived from Penicillium: penicillin G, procaine penicillin, benzathine penicillin, and penicillin V.

Penicillin is sometimes used to treat syphilis, tonsillitis, meningitis, and pneumonia as well as other diseases. It was first used widely during World War II.

Penicillin was discovered when Fleming noticed a mould that was stopping bacteria from growing in a petri dish. [Australian] scientist Howard Walter Florey made the penicillin mould into a medicine. Together with another scientist Ernest Boris Chain, Fleming and Florey were given the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1945.

Some people are allergic to penicillin. Symptoms include nausea, diarrhea, or rash. Rarely, patients who are allergic to penicillin get a fever, vomit, or have serious skin irritation. Because it is such a popular antibiotic, penicillin is the most common cause of serious allergic reactions to a drug. They are now used regularly in hospitals.

question.introduction:
• Who are the people who alter Penicillin to ensure it continues to work?
  • In what year was it first found to work?
  • What was the nationality of the person who first made it into a medicine?
  • Where thing does it come from in nature?

questiontext.text:
Victoria was Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from 20 June 1837 until her death in [1901]. From 1 May 1876, she adopted the additional title of Empress of India.

Victoria was the daughter of [Edward], the fourth son of King George III. Both the Duke of Kent and King George III died in 1820, and Victoria was raised under close supervision by her [German] mother Princess Victoria of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld. She inherited the throne aged [18], after her father's three elder brothers had all died, leaving no surviving legitimate children. The United Kingdom was already an established constitutional monarchy, in which the sovereign held relatively little direct political power. Privately, Victoria attempted to influence government policy and ministerial appointments; publicly, she became a national icon who was identified with strict standards of personal morality.

Victoria married her [cousin], Prince [Albert] of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, in 1840. Their nine children married into royal and noble families across the continent, tying them together and earning her the sobriquet "the grandmother of Europe". After Albert's death in 1861, Victoria plunged into deep mourning and avoided public appearances. As a result of her seclusion, republicanism temporarily gained strength, but in the latter half of her reign her popularity recovered.

question.introduction:
Answer each question by selecting one word

  • What was the first name of Queen Victorias father? 
  • In what year did Queen victoria die?
  • What was the first name of her husband
  • How was she related to her husband?
  • How old was she when she became queen?
  • What was the nationality of her mother?

questiontext.text:
Scotland is a country in North Western [Europe], which is part of the United Kingdom. It is the northern half of the island of Great Britain, with a population of about five million. Scotland shares a border with England. Scotland has coasts on the North Sea to the east, the Atlantic Ocean to the west and the Irish Sea to the south-west.

Scotland was once an independent country with its own monarch, but is now in a union with England, Wales and Northern Ireland; known as the United Kingdom. In 1603, the King of Scotland, James VI, became King of England too, because Queen Elizabeth I of England died. In [1707], the parliament of Scotland joined with the parliament of England to become the parliament of Great Britain.

The capital city of Scotland is the city of Edinburgh, on the east coast. The biggest city is [Glasgow]. Other cities in Scotland are Aberdeen, Dundee, Inverness, Perth and Stirling. The north of Scotland has many mountains, and few people live there. 

Football is the most popular sport in Scotland. The two most famous teams in Scotland are known as the "Old Firm". These are Celtic and Rangers. These two [Glasgow] clubs have a lot of history, and are fierce rivals, often causing fights and riots between the fans.

question.introduction:
• In what year were the Scottish and English parliaments joined?
  • What continent is Scotland in?
  • What city are the two most famous football teams from?
  • What is the largest city in Scotland?

questiontext.text:
William Shakespeare was an [English] poet, playwright, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's pre-eminent dramatist. He is often called England's national poet, and the "Bard of Avon".His extant works, including collaborations, consist of approximately 38 plays,154 sonnets, two long narrative poems, and a few other verses, some of uncertain authorship. His plays have been translated into every major living language and are performed more often than those of any other playwright.

Shakespeare was born in [1564] and brought up in [Stratford-upon-Avon]. At the age of 18, he married [Anne] Hathaway, with whom he had three children: Susanna, and twins Hamnet and Judith. Sometime between 1585 and 1592, he began a successful career in London as an actor, writer, and part-owner of a playing company called the Lord Chamberlain's Men, later known as the King's Men. He appears to have retired to Stratford around 1613, at age 49, where he died three years later. One of his most well known works is [Hamlet].

question.introduction:
Select the words that answer the following questions.

  • What was the year of Shakespears birth?
  • What town did he live in when growing up?
  • What was his wifes first name?
  • What was his nationality?
  • What is his most famous play?

questiontext.text: Sir Frances Drake was an [English] sea captain and politican in the time of queen Elisabeth the 1st. He was born and grew up in [Devon]. He Married Mary Newman in 1569. Queen Elizabeth awarded Drake a knighthood aboard the [Golden] [Hind]

question.introduction:
• What was the nationality of Sir Francis Drake
  • What county did he spend his childhood in?
  • What was the name of the ship where he became a Sir? (two words)

questiontext.text:
The London Underground is a system of [electric] trains which are in London, United Kingdom. It is the oldest underground railway in the world. It started running in 1863 as the Metropolitan Railway. After the opening the system was copied in many other cities, for example New York and Madrid. Even though it is called the Underground about half of it is above the ground. The ["Tube"] is a slang name for the London Underground, because the tunnels for some of the lines are round tubes running through the ground.

Underground train systems in other cities may be called [metros] (like the Tyne and Wear Metro in North East England) or subways (Glasgow Subway in Scotland and in most of North America). Subway is used across Britain to refer to underground walkways.

question.introduction:
• What is the informal name used for the London Underground.
  • What is the common name used for underground systems in other cities?
  • What are the trains powered by?

questiontext.text:
The Tower of London is an ancient Norman [stone] fortress in London, England. It stands on the bank of the River Thames, in the oldest part of the city.

The fortress was built by William the Conqueror, King William I, starting in [1078]. The moat was built by Richard I, using water diverted from the River Thames.

The Tower had many uses. Its main function was to protect Norman rule in the years after the conquest. It was a prison, and a place of execution. Today, the Crown Jewels are kept there. This is the collection of jewels owned by the British state, and sometimes worn by the monarch. There is also a museum of armour.

The Tower of London has a collection of [ravens], large black birds of the Crow family. They are taken care of by the staff who work there. The wing feathers are kept short so they cannot fly away. This is because a legend (story) says that if the ravens leave the Tower, the Tower and the Kingdom will fall.

question.introduction:
• What type of bird is kept at the Tower of London
  • What is the tower of London made of?
  • In what year did the normans begin to build the Tower?

questiontext.text: The man walked to the park in the centre of town. He met up with his wife who was waiting by a [bench]. They had [sandwiches] for their lunch.  They held hands while they walked around the [lake] with the ducks. He kissed her and hurried back to [work].

question.introduction:
Each question requires a single word to be selected for the answer

  • What was the water feature mentioned in the text?
  • What was he returning to when he left his wife? 
  • Select the type of seating mentioned? 
  • Select the item they ate?

questiontext.text: In England children typically start school at the age of 5. School leaving age is 16 but until the age of 18 young people must be in education or training. At the age of 16 students take the [GCSE] exams. It is considered important to pass Maths and English at a minimum of grade C. After two more years of study they may take A level exams which are the standard requirement to study for a university degree. A degree typically take [three] years of study. In recent years the proportion of young people going to University has increased greatly. A Scottish first degree typically takes [four] years.

question.introduction:
Select one word to answer each question

  • What are the exams taken before A levels?
  • How many years does it take to get a degree England?
  • How many years does it take to get a degree in Scotland?

questiontext.text:
• What is the biggest city in Wales? 
  • What is the population of Wales? 
  • What country has a border with Wales? 

Wales is a country on the island of Great Britain. It is one of the four countries that make up the United Kingdom. It is to the west of [England], and east of the Irish Sea and Ireland. 

The Welsh language has official status in Wales, even though the majority of the citizens speak English. Approximately [3,000 000] people live in Wales. Most of them live in the southern and eastern parts of the country. 

In this area is the capital and largest city of Wales, [Cardiff], and the next largest city, Swansea.
My name is Peter. My parents also had two other children, [Stephen] and Jane.

question.introduction: What is my brothers name?

questiontext.text: My name is [William], though everyone except my father calls me Bill. I enjoyed all my subjects at school but my two favourite were Music and [Maths]. Because I wanted to be an engineer I decided that Music would not be very helpful and dropped it in my last year of school. I still enjoy playing [piano] every day and I am thinking of taking up the guitar.

question.introduction:
• What subject did William study in his last year at school?
  • What name does his father call him?
  • What musical instrument does he play?

questiontext.text:
York is a historic walled city in North Yorkshire, England. The Romans called it Eboracum, and the Vikings called it [Jorvik].
The city has been important in many political events in its two millennia of existence. The city offers a wealth of historic attractions, of which York Minster is the most prominent. There are many cultural and sporting activities making it a popular tourist destination for millions.
The city was founded by the [Romans] as in 71 AD. It was later the capital of the kingdoms of Northumbria and Jorvik. In the Middle Ages, York grew as a major [wool] trading centre and became the capital of the northern province of the Church of England, a role it still has. About 130,000 people live in York. It was the traditional county town of Yorkshire but it is no longer.
The centre of York is [medieval]. It has famous old streets and a cathedral called York Minster. To the west of York is Leeds, Wetherby and Harrogate. To the south of York is Selby to the north of York is Easingwold and to the east of York is Scarborough.

question.introduction:
• What group founded York
  • What era does the middle of York date from
  • What was the major commodity traded in the Middle Ages
  • What was the viking name of York?

questiontext.text: We put piled the boxes on the [sidewalk], then when the car arrived put them in the [trunk]. We checked we had a tank of [gas] and set off.

question.introduction: Select the americanisms

questiontext.text: My best friend at school lived in a very large house. They had several fancy cars and a pool. However his [mom] was rarely at home and his father left when he was 12 years old. He used to spend a lot of time at our house and we became like brothers.

question.introduction: Select the americanism/s

questiontext.text: My father worked in finance and always wore a suit and white shirt with [suspenders]. He would polish his shoes on Sunday evening but no matter how dirty they got would not polish them again for a week.

question.introduction: Select the americanism/s

questiontext.text: Someone had thrown mud on my car. I filled the bucket from the [faucet],I added detergent and threw half of it over the [hood]. I then cleaned off the rest of the mess.

question.introduction: Spot the americanisms

questiontext.text: We arrived at the same time and talked about the meeting in the [elevator]. When we arrived in the room the other people were already sitting. I opened my laptop and introduced myself.

question.introduction: Spot the Americanism

questiontext.text: When I was at school my favourite subject was [math]. I liked history and english and my teachers were very helpful. However I didn't really enjoy school until I was in my teens.

question.introduction: Select the americanism/s

questiontext.text: We stopped at the shops and my brother went into the [drugstore]. Our favourite cafe was shut so we bought some fruit and orange juice. We were there for about half an hour.

question.introduction: Select the americanism/s

questiontext.text: The [busboy] dropped a pile of plates and while everyone was distracted  someone stole my laptop.

question.introduction: Spot the americanisms

questiontext.text: In the [fall] we would sit on the [sidewalk] and watch the people walk by. My brother would play the guitar and we would sing close harmony.

question.introduction: Select the words that are more commonly used in American English rather than British English.

questiontext.text: Despite working all night we had [gotten] nowhere with the problem. Neither of us were good at [math] and we decided to call my brother who is good at this type of work..

question.introduction: Spot the americanism

category.text: $course$/top/Default for qb/Wordselect English Language Questions/Spot the error

questiontext.text: My laptop would not connect to the internet so I had to [altar] the settings.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: I met my wife ten years [before]. We were on an English language course and I helped her learn grammar. We fell in love and got married.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: My generation grew up without personal or mobile devices. I was born [on] 1960 and I was a teenager before I saw my first computer.

question.introduction: Select the incorrectly used words

questiontext.text: Last year I [brought] my first house. I had been saving for the deposit [since] five years and I was very excited when I received the front door key.

question.introduction: Select the words that are used incorrectly.

questiontext.text: He said he would write the essay and he has [did] what he said he would.

question.introduction: Select the incorrectly used word

questiontext.text: When I studied computer science we were taught the [different] between variables and constants. As the name suggests constants have a fixed value that cannot be changed.
Thank you for coming over, I am delighted to see you. Would you [make] me a favor and help me move the table?.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: I spent an hour explaining the past tense to him, but he still [don't] understand it.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: My headache was better by the morning and I didn't need [no] painkillers.

question.introduction: Select the incorrectly used word

questiontext.text: I had been playing guitar for five years before I did my first live performance. I practiced [during] four hours on the night before that first show.

question.introduction: Select the word that has been used in correctly

questiontext.text: My youngest son started at school in September. He enjoys classes and the teachers tell me he is doing [good].

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly.

questiontext.text: My brother studied for seven years to become a doctor. He worked very hard and now he [am] very successful.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: My mother now lives with [she's] sister.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly.

questiontext.text: Since you explained how to work it I [am] now understand what to do.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: When I was at school my teacher [learnt] me how to write computer programs. I was a good student and learned [fastly].

question.introduction: Select the words that are used incorrectly

questiontext.text: My car was being fixed so my brother [borrowed] me his. It is much newer than mine and I enjoyed driving it.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: A person who looks after mens hair is called a barber. A person who looks after womens hair is [name] a hairdresser. Men tend to spend [fewer] money on their hair than women. However the often take more care if it begins to fall out, as most men do not want to go [bold].

question.introduction: Select the words that are used correctly.

questiontext.text: My father was [borned] in Yorkshire, but he [growed] up in the county of Kent. He was a good student at school, and by the age of 10 he was taller [then] his older brother.

question.introduction: Select the words that have been used incorrectly.

questiontext.text: I do not speak French very [good] and so I am going on a course, that lasts [since] three months.

question.introduction: Select the words that have been used incorrectly.

questiontext.text: I sent a present to my cousin [that] lives in Australia. He has been there [since] six months now.

question.introduction: Select the incorrectly used words.

questiontext.text: My brother loved to play sports, but I am completely [disinterested]. He spent the summer playing cricket, the winter playing football and he played badminton all year.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: The man [which] sold me the car had a French accent. He had been in the country for three years.

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: I passed the interview and I now have a new [work]

question.introduction: Select the word that is used incorrectly

questiontext.text: My [father] was a policeman and my [mother] was a teacher.  I am two years older than my [brother] and my [sister] is a year younger than me.

question.introduction: Find the (up and down)

questiontext.text: My granfather was a [farmer] who lived until he was 90 years old. His wife (my grandmother) was known as a beauty and I have many photographs from when they were young. My own father was an [engineer] and worked in the car industry. I have worked with computers as a [programmer], mainly in the area of education.

question.introduction: Select the words in the text that are the names of jobs.

questiontext.text: horse cow [whale ]dog [shark] zebra

question.introduction: Pick the ones that live in water

questiontext.text:
I went shopping to the supermarket and bought a mop, [bread], [rice] and [milk]. On the way back I 

stopped at the corner shop and bought a newspaper and some [chocolate].

question.introduction: Select the words that name food.

questiontext.text: One of my favourite recipes is Catalan chicken stew. This includes Chicken, Chorizo and the skin of an [orange]. I also like Pavlova (a type of merangue) with [strawberries] and [raspberries].

question.introduction: Select the words that are the names of fruit in this text.

questiontext.text: [football] [cricket] orange [tennis] pencil [rugby]

question.introduction: Which of the following are sports?

questiontext.text: cat [bat] dog [eagle] cow horse

question.introduction: Which of these can fly?

questiontext.text: People in the UK are very keen on pets. The [cat] and [dog] are two of the most popular. People also keep [rabbits] and keeping [fish] in tanks is common.

question.introduction: Select the words for types of pet

questiontext.text: We did not have a [car] till I was 12 years old, and we used to travel mainly by [bus] or [train]. I got a [bicycle] for my 10th birthday.

question.introduction: Select the words for ways of transport

[I got up late and hurried my breakfast.] [I caught the train] [but it was delayed]. [The shop was shut when I arrived]. [A man was outside]. [He said] [["where are other the staff?"]]. [I said] ["I don't know."] [he did not look happy]

question.introduction: Select the question in the following text.

answer.text: I got up late and hurried my breakfast.
The shop was shut when I arrived

questiontext.text:
Select the question

[I got up late.] [My brother knocked on the door]. [[He said "what time is the bus?"]]

answer.text: My brother knocked on the door

questiontext.text: [The train came to a stop], [after an hour it had still not moved]. [[I asked john if he had bought any food]]. [All he had was an apple and some chocolate].

question.introduction: Select the question from this text.

answer.text: The train came to a stop
after an hour it had still not moved
[I asked john if he had bought any food
All he had was an apple and some chocolate

questiontext.text: On Sunday afternoon I [worked] in the Garden, then afterwards I  [cooked] a meal for my mother.
I [sat] at home [watching] TV.
